name: Marcelo Fabian Frias
content: UTEP Faculty Profiles MinerAlert Skip to main content Search pages and people FACULTY PROFILES X Quick Links Library Parking & Maps UTEP News Events Student Affairs Business Affairs Employment Opportunities University Bookstore Technology Support Main Content UTEP Faculty Profiles UTEP Faculty Profiles Marcelo F. Frias Professor Computer Science Office Building: Chemistry and Computer Science Building Office Room: 3.1008 Phone: (915) 747-5516 Email: mfrias4@utep.edu Expertise: See Research Profile in Expertise Connector Bio Education Scholarly and Creative Activity Grants Courses Course Evaluations Bio < Dr. Marcelo Frias is a Professor in the Computer Science Department at the University of Texas at El Paso. His research interests are in the area of Automated Software Engineering, with focus on fault detection, test generation, automated program repair and synthesis of specifications. Awards and Honors Marshall of Graduate Students, School of Engineering, Commencement Ceremony - Graduate School, UTEP (12/15/2024) Amazon Research Award - Amazon Web Services (03/01/2021-03/31/2021) Best paper award - IEEE/ACM (05/23/2017) Best paper award - Brazilian Society for Computer Science (11/25/2016) Best Paper Award - European Association for Software Science and Technology (EASST) (03/28/2007) Bernardo Houssay Award to Scientific and Technological Research (young researcher in Computer Science) - Argentinean Secretary of Science and Technology (05/01/2003-05/31/2003) > Education < Ph D in Computer Science, Pontifcia Universidade Catolica in Rio de Janeiro (1998) BS in Computer Science, Universidad de Buenos Aires (1992) > Publications < An Analysis of the Impact of Field-Value Instance Navigation in Alloy’s Model Finding Rigorous State-Based Methods (ABZ 2024, Springer) LNCS 14759 (2024), Cesar Cornejo, Maria Marta Novaira, Sonia Parmigiani, Nazareno Aguirre, Marcelo Frias, Simon Gutierrez Brida, German Regis. Discrete Structures II 14423 Evaluation > Bio Bio Dr. Marcelo Frias is a Professor in the Computer Science Department at the University of Texas at El Paso. His research interests are in the area of Automated Software Engineering, with focus on fault detection, test generation, automated program repair and synthesis of specifications.
